text:
Used to be you could just walk out your door
and stumble on a new element.
OK, maybe not quite that easy.

This year four new elements officially made
it on the periodic table, completing the seventh
row.

But have we found all the elements that are
out there?

The first recorded discovery of an element
was phosphorus, symbol P, which was isolated
in 1669 from -- you guessed it -- pee.

Elements like copper and gold were known for
millennia before that.

But it wasn’t until the late 1700s when
the modern ideas of chemistry emerged and

people recognized that elements were substances
that could not be decomposed into two or more
other types of stuff.
That sparked a bit of an element gold rush.

Some elements were found by careful measurement
of boiling points.
Others were discovered in the air.

Many were discovered in ores and minerals
collected around the world, including seven
from a single mine in Ytterby, Sweden.

Every element from 1 to 92 had been found
in nature by 1939, with one exception - looking
at you technetium!

Every element that came after was made in
the lab.
Why?

Many elements after uranium aren’t stable
enough to last very long in the real world.

Plutonium 246 is like a junior high romance,
having a half-life of about 10 days -- in

other words, it takes about 10 days for half
of that plutonium to decay into lighter, more
stable elements.
Some of these elements just last a few seconds.

Since we’re not going to find them out in
the wild, chemists and physicists have to
make them in a lab.

And how does one go about making an element,
exactly?
With particle accelerators.

The king of these monster machines, the Large
Hadron Collider at CERN, can boost protons
to near the speed of light.

Quick recap about atoms: they have positively
charged protons and neutral neutrons in a

densely packed nucleus, with clouds of negatively
charged electrons around them.

Stable atomic nuclei hold together thanks
to something called, no kidding, the strong
force.

But protons don’t really like each other
- just like two north ends of magnets coming

near each other, repulsion between those positive
protons tear bigger atoms apart.

Think of it as a crowded subway car -- just
like people, the more protons that get crammed
into a space, the more they want to get out.

Sometimes called atom smashers, particle accelerators
fire neutrons or even whole nuclei at ludicrously

high speed into larger atoms, and scientists
look for new elements in the shrapnel.

Chemists like Glenn T. Seaborg figured this
out in the 1940s.

He started by firing off some deuterium nuclei
at uranium.

That resulted in a new element named after
everyone’s favorite dwarf planet, plutonium.

And once you get a new element this way, you
can fire other particles at it to make even
heavier elements.

But finding new elements got harder as they
got heavier since particle accelerators can’t
handle heavier elements.

So scientists needed heavy ion accelerators
and more sensitive detectors to get to the
next batch of elements.

Eventually, chemists and physicists were able
to fill in elements 93 through 118.
But why go through all this trouble?

Well, some of those earlier human-made elements
found practical purposes, like plutonium to
power space probes or americium in smoke detectors.

Scientists also want to find new elements
so they can test theories about how atoms
behave.

Since atoms, you know, make up everything,
it’s important to confirm or challenge those
ideas.

Despite some good attempts, we haven’t seen
any success in the hunt for elements 119 or

See, when scientists made element 118, they
smashed calcium ions into the element californium.

In the same way, they wanted want to use einsteinium
as the target for element 119.

But there simply isn’t enough einsteinium
in the world to make that experiment possible.

At some point though, these huge elements
are just going to get too big to be stable.

Right now, some of the highest numbered elements
only exist for a few thousandths of a second
or less.

It’s possible that some might not even last
long enough to be detected.

It may be that element 121 is just not meant
to be.

Because of the way neutrons and protons arrange
themselves in atomic nuclei, certain atomic

numbers make for a more stable nucleus - these
combinations are called “magic numbers”.

It’s possible that element 114 is a magic
number nucleus; or maaaybe it’s element
120, or maybe element 126.

But there is no guarantee that we’ll ever
get that far.
So, to sum up, have we found all the elements?
Probably not... but we might be getting close.

So welcome newest elements nihonium, moscovium,
tennessine, and oganesson!
What would you call element 119?

Let us know in the comments and check out
these videos for more elemental goodness.
Thanks for watching!
